section.title: Verbs with two objects
section.sectiontitle: Some verbs can be followed by two objects (a direct object and an indirect object). The indirect object usually refers to a person and comes first.
section.text1a: He gave his wife some earrings for her birthday.
section.text2a: The police gave my brother a speeding ticket.
section.sectiontitle2: We can also put the indirect object after the direct object. In this case, we use to before the indirect object.
section.text3a: He gave some earrings to his wife for her birthday.
section.text4a: The police gave a speeding ticket to my brother.

section.title: Verbs with two objects
section.sectiontitle: It is more natural to use verb + indirect object + direct object, especially when the indirect object is a pronoun (me, you, him, her, it, us, them).
section.text1a: He gave her some earrings for her birthday.
section.text2a: I sent you a cheque yesterday.
section.sectiontitle2: Common verbs which use this construction are give, bring, offer, lend, owe, send, tell, promise, buy, teach, show, write.
